title: A font which suggest French Cinema through the ages....
content:
Hi,  
I was interested in what fonts people associated with  
a) Cinema and film  
b) French Cinema and film through History

I understand this is wide open to a lot of interpretation!  
If it helps the cover will include a still from the French film " The Artist" (Black and white film, but made in 2011).  
 [http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1655442/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415100608/http:/www.imdb.com/title/tt1655442/ "http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1655442/")

The client has asked for a bold modern cover (ha).  
Though the actual film is a modern interpretation of a silent movie.

Cheers,

Jason
author: Rawshock Design

comments.content: Something French with a modern feel to it... you could look into [Peignot Bold](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415100608/http:/typophile.com/wiki/https%3A/%252Fwww.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/peignot/bold/). Another [showing](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415100608/http:/www.identifont.com/similar?GMZ) of this well-known face.

About the typography of “The Artist” (that should have been lettering): [http://www.marksimonson.com/notebook/view/the-artist-vs-the-lettering-ar...](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415100608/http:/www.marksimonson.com/notebook/view/the-artist-vs-the-lettering-artist "http://www.marksimonson.com/notebook/view/the-artist-vs-the-lettering-artist")

A typeface inspired by french cinema (albeit a specific fraction of it): [http://carvalho-bernau.com/jlg/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415100608/http:/carvalho-bernau.com/jlg/ "http://carvalho-bernau.com/jlg/")

Hi Both,

Thank you I have tried the various options you have suggested on layout. Some interesting covers developing.  
One font that is looking nice is Parisian BT .  
I also think the Jean-Luc Godard’s font could look really interesting used really big and covering most of the image. I doubt the publisher would go for it, but I will try it in any case. Because you never know.

When I think of the history of French cinema, I think of _auteurs_ who were formally innovative—e.g. Melies, Gance, Cocteau, Godard, and now Hazanavicius.

While it’s true that Cassandre’s Peignot was also formally innovative in its day, it has rather a traditional art deco look, even in the true unicase setting.

Why not go with something post-modern that suggests innovation today?  
Pierre di Sciullo: [http://www.quiresiste.com/realisations.php?lang=en](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415100608/http:/www.quiresiste.com/realisations.php?lang=en "http://www.quiresiste.com/realisations.php?lang=en")

Excoffon, 20th century master: [https://www.myfonts.com/person/Roger\_Excoffon/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415100608/https:/www.myfonts.com/person/Roger_Excoffon/ "https://www.myfonts.com/person/Roger\_Excoffon/")

I immediately thought of Cahiers du Cinema. Perhaps a review of its covers over the years would provide some inspiration:

[https://www.google.com/search?q=Cahiers+du+Cinema&client=firefox-a&hs=l2...](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415100608/https:/www.google.com/search?q=Cahiers+du+Cinema&client=firefox-a&hs=l2d&rls=org.mozilla:en-US:official&channel=sb&tbm=isch&tbo=u&source=univ&sa=X&ei=awRPVL3kCYeYyQS2rYDoAQ&ved=0CEIQsAQ&biw=1303&bih=874 "https://www.google.com/search?q=Cahiers+du+Cinema&client=firefox-a&hs=l2d&rls=org.mozilla:en-US:official&channel=sb&tbm=isch&tbo=u&source=univ&sa=X&ei=awRPVL3kCYeYyQS2rYDoAQ&ved=0CEIQsAQ&biw=1303&bih=874")

And I second trying the Jean-Luc Godard typeface….

Hi Nick,

Thanks for sending me Excoffons way. I know some of his fonts but had no idea they were by a French Foundry/designer. Mistral looks a bit American to me for some reason.  
They are the sort of fonts I would dismiss often as they are so unique/different.  
That is very often a reason for using them of course as design is often about making a statement/making something unique. Banco is a really interesting one.

Hi Kthomps5,  
Thanks I will have a look at your link. I have done a layout already using the Jean-Luc Godard face.  
It's certainly got power on the page and looks really modern somehow. Seems a little similar to Knockout.  
Don't know if I can do the kind of Justification Jean-Luc uses in his title sequences though.  
It just doesn't sit well to my eye, though many designers would disagree.

Recent Criterion idea of what looks like French cinema lettering

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415100608im_/http:/typophile.com/files/CriterionTati_5965.jpg)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415100608im_/http:/typophile.com/files/CriterionTati2_5678.jpg)
  
Don

A general specific french cinema style? Hardly to grasp. Let Google sort out images to “cinema français affiche” and you’ll see – everything. But looking for “cinema français affiche 1930” reveals a different scenery: type like [Marlowe](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415100608/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/facetype/marlowe/) or the stunning [Mostra Nuova](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415100608/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/marksimonson/mostra-nuova/) by – Mark Simonson. To him I’m especially grateful for his intricate review of type in the film The Artist. For a very long time I feel that lettering and type is awkwardly neglected by film makers, mostly. Mark’s article opened my eyes upon how crucial (!) script and lettering is for a silent movie in particular.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415100608im_/http:/typophile.com/files/brain_4880.png)
  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415100608im_/http:/typophile.com/files/rauchen_6502.png)

Thanks Andreas for sharing the asymmetrical Body and Brain lettering. I can't recall if this is now a digital font but it leaves no doubt that it's circa 1932.  
I'll add it to my collection with Florida and similar lettering from the era like:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415100608im_/http:/typophile.com/files/LetteringAsymmetricalThickandThinSM_3832.jpg)
  
Don

Only semi-asymmetrical but otherwise similar to Body and Brain, Ultra Modern circa 1928. the upper case:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415100608im_/http:/typophile.com/files/UltraModernUC_3516.gif)
  [https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/redrooster/ultra-modern-rr/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415100608/https:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/redrooster/ultra-modern-rr/ "https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/redrooster/ultra-modern-rr/")  
Don

A great French film from 1953, the Wages of Fear, uses thick and thin lettering similar to Peignot, but without the quirky features of the lowercase.  
Don
